title-group.article-title: Accordion effect in a thin-strut coronary stent

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Cardiology, Sema Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey
2Department of Cardiology, Kosuyolu Cardiovascular Research and Training Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Soe Moe Aung Yalı Mah Sahil Yolu Sok No:16 Dragos 34844 Maltepe Istanbul Turkey Email: soemoe@gmail.com

abstract.p: Longitudinal compression (accordion effect) of modern thinner-strut stents has been recently recognised. We report a typical case of longitudinal stent compression caused by a post-dilatation balloon.

sec.title: Case
sec.p: A 41-year-old female patient presented with unstable angina pectoris. Her coronary angiogram showed critical stenoses in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the right coronary artery (RCA). The mid and proximal LAD lesions were predilated with a 2.5-20 mm balloon. The mid segment was stented successfully without incident. Subsequently, a 2.5-28 mm Promus® Element stent (Boston Scientific Corp., Natick, MA, USA) (Figure 1, panel B) was implanted in the proximal lesion. Then, a 2.75-15 mm non-compliant balloon was advanced for the post-dilatation of the proximal Promus® Element stent. Although there was some resistance while advancing the balloon, it was passed into the stented segment. While imaging for positioning of the balloon, the implanted Promus® stent was found to be shortened significantly (Figure 1, panel C). When measured, the original stent length of 28 mm was found to be shortened to 21 mm. As the final result was technically satisfactory, no further stenting was performed (Figure 1, panel D).

caption.p: A: LAD lesion before intervention; B: A 2.5-28 mm Promus® Element stent was deployed; C: Compression of the proximal stent was easily seen when the wire in the side branch was taken as a reference. The 2.75-15 mm NC balloon is seen dilated within the stent; D: Final result after post-dilatation

sec.title: Comment
sec.p: Longitudinal stent compression is a recently recognised complication of modern stent platforms. Although thin-strut stents have the advantage of increased deliverability and flexibility, they seem to have lower longitudinal strength. In a recent report, stent deformation was reported to occur in 0.097% of stents deployed.1 Longitudinal stent deformation was seen most commonly with Promus® Element stents and the rate was reported to be 0.86%.1 In a laboratory experiment to assess the longitudinal strength of modern stents, a certain amount of force (50 gram force) was applied and the stents of the offset peak-to-peak design category (Element stent platform) had an average longitudinal compression of 13.20 mm (longitudinal compression of 47.07%), showing a markedly lower resistance to longitudinal compression than the other platforms.2 The reported mechanisms of

longitudinal deformation are guide catheter compression of osteal stents, compression by proximal embolic protection catheter or Guideliner catheter and compression by post-dilatation balloon that would not readily pass into the stent deployed.1,3 In most of the reported cases, compression was caused by the guide catheter or another device, mostly to the stents deployed in the osteal location. In our case, the longitudinal compression was caused by a post-dilatation balloon in a non-osteal location. The treatment of this complication often requires the use of a series of dilatation balloons, depending on the extent of compression.

It is important to recognize this relatively new complication of modern stents quickly. Otherwise, it could pose as a nidus for stent thrombosis. Moreover, the diseased segment could have been left uncovered by the stent. Our case and recently reported similar cases suggest that manufacturers should not neglect the importance of longitudinal strength in designing future stents.
